name: herald-for-android
description: Herald for Android - Reliable mobile Bluetooth communications - Android library & test app
interact_justification:
Obtain: https://heraldprox.io/download
Provide feedback/Contribute: https://heraldprox.io/community
Repo also has a contributing.md file
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/theheraldproject/herald-for-android/blob/develop/contributing.md>.
contribution_requirements_justification: https://heraldprox.io/contribute - Contributor's guide (being created today and uploaded. Should be available from Monday 17th May 2021)
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/theheraldproject/herald-for-android/blob/develop/LICENSE.txt>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
Project documentation guide (multiple repo project).

Developers/Integration guide: https://heraldprox.io/guide/
documentation_interface_justification:
Design guide: https://heraldprox.io/design/
Herald formal Standards guides: https://heraldprox.io/specs/

We also work with ETSI and others on international standards.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: We have -beta1/ beta2 semver tags for intermediate releases. We have a public develop branch, and a public master/main branch with v tags for releases from either (depending on whether they are interim releases or not).
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_tags_justification: We use v* tags. E.g. v1.0, v1.2-beta1
release_notes_vulns_justification: We don't publish a release if there is a known vulnerability to our code.
report_process_justification:
https://github.com/theheraldproject/herald-for-android/issues

We also provide templates for issues/features.
enhancement_responses_justification: We aim to respond within 5 days
report_archive_justification:
We only close issues, never delete them.
https://github.com/theheraldproject/herald-for-android/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aclosed
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: As per SECURITY.md file. The Linux Foundation Public Health currently does not have a standard policy or reporting mechanism (E.g. HackerOne) which we can use. I've raised this as an issue for the next TAC meeting. https://github.com/theheraldproject/herald-for-android/blob/develop/SECURITY.md
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: As per SECURITY.md file. The Linux Foundation Public Health currently does not have a standard policy or reporting mechanism (E.g. HackerOne) which we can use. I've raised this as an issue for the next TAC meeting.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: We respond to all issue reports within 5 days. We have issued security patches in the past within 24 hours: https://github.com/theheraldproject/herald-for-android/releases/tag/v1.1.1
build_justification: Gradle build system for local (developer, adopter) and automated CI (project release via GitHub Actions) builds
build_common_tools_justification: We use GitHub Actions and GitHub Packages where possible. We also use the appropriate packaging approach for each system (E.g. Maven Central for this Android repo)
test_justification: Standard approach via gradle test. Branch protection rules for this to be ran for every PR to the develop or master/main branches.
test_most_justification: Currently covers all core library features. Elements requiring 2 device Bluetooth communication cannot be tested with unit tests, but we have a manual mechanism for this too. We abstract as much into classes as possible so there's little to test physically outside of unit tests.
test_policy_justification: This is a standard policy. We require developers to use Test Driven Development.
tests_are_added_justification: We have just implemented a GitHub CI system that archives the test output HTML for every test as an artifact for each build (which is required for every single PR now). This is new though. There is a major (v2.0) version being released in the coming days adhering to this that all repos will adopt.
tests_documented_added_justification: It is documented in the new Contributor's guide (published 17 May 2021): https://heraldprox.io/contribute
warnings_fixed_justification: Every major release requires that all warnings are addressed, or documented and ignores with a link to the documentation where the ignore instruction is present. (Not applicable for Android, but the Zephyr C++ build system has such warnings, which is well known in that community).
warnings_strict_justification: For the Android/Java project this is done.
know_secure_design_justification: Myself (Adam Fowler) in the core committer team and as TSC Chair has this knowledge. Other contributors (not committers) do too.
know_common_errors_justification: I (Adam Fowler) has experience of this from industry, including OWASP and mobile application scanning tools. I am also familiar with NCSC secure coding requirements.
crypto_published_justification:
RandomSource supports various options. We use the SecureRandom's backup option as we have to support old phones (Dating back to 2010) and old versions of Android that would otherwise block indefinitely, leading to poor epidemiological efficacy for older phones (and thus would disproportionately negatively effect poorer people).
See these classes for examples of security steps taken:-
- https://github.com/theheraldproject/herald-for-android/tree/develop/herald/src/main/java/io/heraldprox/herald/sensor/datatype/random
- https://github.com/theheraldproject/herald-for-android/blob/develop/herald/src/main/java/io/heraldprox/herald/sensor/datatype/PseudoDeviceAddress.java
- https://github.com/theheraldproject/herald-for-android/blob/develop/herald/src/main/java/io/heraldprox/herald/sensor/payload/simple/K.java
crypto_call_justification: We use provided cryptography where possible. There is a need in next version of the project to implement our own handshake and token mechanism to prevent relay and replay attacks over the wire. That will use DH and TOTP as a basis though. Initial design can be seen here: https://heraldprox.io/specs/payload-secured
crypto_floss_justification: Both our library and any dependencies will be Apache-2.0. OpenJDK implementations of core crypto features are available for Java primitives.
crypto_keylength_justification: Met where applicable. Library adopters can configure a range of options, and plug in their own where needed.
crypto_working_justification: We follow NIST SP recommendations and NCSC recommendations.
crypto_pfs_justification:
This is the preferred approach but in an anonymous system there are limits to what can be achieved. E.g. for the 'simple payload' a daily key is used to forward generate the 5 minute expiring 'ephemeral keys' for digital contact tracing. This is a 'good thing', as less information needs to be transmitted across mobile networks for devices to realise they have had exposure to an ill person. The identity behind this daily key is not known, and only transmitted to devices after the event and after individuals have been diagnosed. (This is the same way GAEN works).
A new Secured Payload will provide this mechanism in a different way. This will use 'tokens' issued over an encrypted mechanism where this token is only exchanged with that device. This will be generated in such a way as to provide for perfect forward secrecy. (There will not be a common key basis to each token).
crypto_password_storage_justification: We don't store secrets. Where key storage features are used, we delegate this to the host OS. (E.g. it's managed in their secure enclaves, where available).
crypto_random_justification: Used where provided by the host device. Where enough entropy is not provided (old Android phones), an external source of additional entropy is used to change the random bytes generated.
delivery_mitm_justification:
Source code: https and git+ssh source access. Builds on GitHub actions natively.
Bluetooth transfer: Only certain approaches possible with completely anonymous data exchange. New Secured Payload will issue tokens and hash responses from devices, so even if the originating transfer is MITM'ed, the resultant 'exposure' data would fail to be authenticated.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: No confirmed vulnerabilities. All security mechanisms can also be replaced / switched out by downstream adopters of the library to more secure versions. Due to the wide range of android (SDK 21) and iOS (9.3+) devices we have to support, some options are more secure than others, but adopters can choose their preferred approach for all security functions.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: Only time this has been necessary the fix was issued within 24 hours of the project team being notified.
static_analysis_justification: Spotbugs now part of the unit_test GitHub Actions workflow, and ran on every PR to the develop or master/main branches as a pre-requisite check. This check also applies to administrators and cannot be bypassed.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Spotbugs now part of the unit_test GitHub Actions workflow, and ran on every PR to the develop or master/main branches as a pre-requisite check. This check also applies to administrators and cannot be bypassed. We also use the findsecbugs plugin to spotbugs.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: A PR cannot be merged without tests passing, including static analysis (as of today). Standard issue report fix (E.g. new vulns, old code) have a target SLA of 5 days.
static_analysis_often_justification: We use gitflow so commits happen on forks. Every PR though has these required. (I.e. a commit set cannot be merged without these passing).
general_comments: It's a suite of project repositories with a common goal: Reliable presence detection, distance estimation, and data transfer between devices. This is aimed at providing eHealth approaches and benefits, both through Digital Contact Tracing (DCT) but also in helping other eHealth areas, including more efficient hospital operations.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: We do this where possible but we don't always use the very latest approaches. This is because, uniquely, we have to support platforms back to iOS 9.3 and Android SDK 21 in order to be widely usable on a very wide range of mobile devices so that poorer communities have access to life saving technology in our Digital Contact Tracing and eHealth solutions. Where a 'lowest common denominator' approach is used, we ensure that adopters can switch in/out a more secure provided algorithm, or replace it with their own algorithm. This allows us to provide maximum reach and recommend best practice without disadvantaging poor communities.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: GitHub Actions has just been implemented.
discussion_justification:
GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.

There's is also an LFPH Slack instance with herald-* named channels. https://slack.lfph.io/
no_leaked_credentials_justification: GitHub secrets are used for the build pipeline. No repository contains secrets, usernames, or passwords.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
maintained_justification: Herald is a Tier 2 (soon Tier 3) Project within the Linux Foundation Public Health (LFPH). This requires minimum standards for community size. Submitter is the TSC Chair for 2021-2022.

name: openvidu
description: OpenVidu is a platform to facilitate the addition of video calls in your web or mobile application. It provides a complete stack of technologies very easy to integrate in your application. Our main goal is to allow developers to add real-time communications to their apps very fast and with low impact in their code.
contribution_justification: https://github.com/OpenVidu/openvidu/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/OpenVidu/openvidu/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://docs.openvidu.io/en/2.17.0/
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: For example we upload Docker packaged dev versions in order to being able to test them previously to the oficial r2.18.0-dev2.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_tags_justification: Each version is taged in Git, and it is market as a release on https://github.com/OpenVidu/openvidu/releases where the releases note can be found
release_notes_justification: We post releases notes in medium  (eg. https://openvidu.medium.com/openvidu-2-17-0-enjoy-scalable-recordings-and-forced-codecs-3d870c5b047d) and link them in the  https://github.com/OpenVidu/openvidu/releases
release_notes_vulns_justification: In the release notes there will be specific section when addressing vulnerabilities. Currently we haven't been reported any run-time vulnerability so no fixes needed so far.
report_tracker_justification: We use the GitHub issues tracker for users to report issues/bugs. https://github.com/OpenVidu/openvidu/issues
report_process_justification: We use the GitHub issues tracker for users to report issues/bugs. https://github.com/OpenVidu/openvidu/issues
report_responses_justification: Most if not all the bugs and issues reported have been aknowledged. Can be publicly checked here: https://github.com/OpenVidu/openvidu/issues
enhancement_responses_justification: Most if not all the enhancements requested have been aknowledged, even not always have been deemed as prioritary or even worth to have. Can be publicly checked here: https://github.com/OpenVidu/openvidu/labels/enhancement
report_archive_justification: GitHub saves the history of all reports opened (enhancements/bugs/issues) and it is publicily available  https://github.com/OpenVidu/openvidu/issues
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: Any vulnerability can be reported in the GitHub issues tab.  https://github.com/OpenVidu/openvidu/issues
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: We don't specifically support private vulnerability reports, but if any user feels the need the private reports can be sended using the contact email hello@openvidu.opencollective.com
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: We haven't had vulnerability reports yet.
build_floss_tools_justification: The tool is able to build only using Maven  (FLOSS)
test_justification: Each of the modules in the main repository contains its own test suite: eg. https://github.com/OpenVidu/openvidu/tree/master/openvidu-server/src/test
test_invocation_justification: As the modules are mainly Maven Java projects the test suite can be run with mvn test
test_policy_justification: When a functionality is added directly by the OpenVidu team it is always backed by the relevant tests that are included in the repository. And for new functionality added by the community it is requested that in order for that PR to be evaluated and merged the relevant tests should be provided.
tests_documented_added_justification: There isn't a specific test policy regarding which tests should be added when adding a new functionality, as the set of use cases is vast. OpenVidu team would review each PR and deem if the tests provided are enough evidence for validating the new functionality.
delivery_mitm_justification: We delegate the secutirty to our standard distribution mechanisms. Deb repositories verify all the packages with a unique GPG for each project this way even HTTP downloads can be granted as secured. On the other hand we deliver the software as Docker images publicly hosted on DockerHub and we relay on the download security mechanism DockerHub may implement.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: We prioritize vulnerabilities and crashes over any other issue or request for changes.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: We prioritize vulnerabilities and crashes over any other issue or request for changes.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: Any code release that fails in the Jenkins jobs aren't merged into the main branches so it won't be released.
dynamic_analysis_justification: Instead of embedding run-time assertions, there are many external tests with assertions that are checked during automated testing. There is even e2e testing executed automatically before any release (even nightlies releases) https://github.com/OpenVidu/openvidu/tree/master/openvidu-test-e2e
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Instead of embedding run-time assertions, there are many external tests with assertions that are checked during automated testing. There is even e2e testing executed automatically before any release (even nightlies releases)
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: If any issue is found it is immediately taken care of, and the release would be held on hold until it is solved.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: The project has a full suite of tests included in the main repository. This tests covers internal functionalities as well as e2e tests that cover the server functionality from the users perspective.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests. And we have also an specific discourse group https://openvidu.discourse.group/
no_leaked_credentials_justification: We have example of credentials in the repo but not valid private credentials
english_justification: Everything is in English as primary language.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
implementation_languages: Java, TypeScript, Shell, JavaScript, Dockerfile, SCSS
maintained_justification: This project is fairly active and maintained. We have released 3 full version in the last year and we are targeting full releases each 3 months aprox, and minot releases as frequently as needed.

name: FIWARE Short Time Historic (STH) - Comet
description: A component of the FIWARE ecosystem in charge of managing historical and aggregated time series context information
interact_justification: Information described in the following document:  https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-sth-comet/blob/master/doc/manuals/contribution-guidelines.md
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
contribution_requirements_justification: Requirements described in the following document https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-sth-comet/blob/master/doc/manuals/contribution-guidelines.md
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-sth-comet/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The AGPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The AGPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: The directory "doc" contains most documentation. Installation information is at https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-sth-comet/blob/master/doc/manuals/installation.md and other materials are at https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-sth-comet/blob/master/doc
documentation_interface_justification: The interface is defined across different documents this folder: https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-sth-comet/blob/master/doc
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: All versions are put on git, not just final versions.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: The primary development team uses git commit tags to identify releases. Regular umbrella releases aligned with the FIWARE Foundation.
version_tags_justification: Full releases are tagged using 'git tag'.
release_notes_justification: Release notes are included as part of the release in github (for example: https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-sth-comet/releases/tag/2.8.0). In addition, a CHANGES_NEXT_RELEASE file is hold in top directory in master branch (https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-sth-comet/blob/master/CHANGES_NEXT_RELEASE) with the delta of changes for the next release.
release_notes_vulns_justification: There have been no publicly known vulnerabilities
report_process_justification: Yes, GitHub issue tracker. The process is described on the following link: https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-sth-comet/blob/master/doc/manuals/contribution-guidelines.md
report_responses_justification: Yes. This is a requirement for membership of the FIWARE Foundation Catalogue https://www.fiware.org/developers/catalogue/
enhancement_responses_justification: The project has been responding to most enhancement requests.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No external reports so far, so this is vacuously true.
test_justification: Yes, it includes a test suite based on Mocha https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-sth-comet/blob/master/doc/manuals/contribution-guidelines.md#testing
test_invocation_justification: Yes. "npm test" invokes the automated test suite. This is documented in https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-sth-comet/blob/master/doc/manuals/contribution-guidelines.md#testing
test_most_justification: Met. Currently coverage of the codebase is well over 80%. More info here: https://coveralls.io/github/telefonicaid/fiware-sth-comet?branch=master
test_policy_justification: Yes. The contribution policies at https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-sth-comet/blob/master/doc/manuals/contribution-guidelines.md#overview says: "For any new feature added, unit tests must be provided, taking as a reference the ones already created and included in the project."
tests_are_added_justification: Tests are added as new functionality is added. This is verified during the pull request code review, ensuring that proper tests are included in the pull request before merging it.
tests_documented_added_justification: Yes, at the contribution policies at https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-sth-comet/blob/master/doc/manuals/contribution-guidelines.md#branching-model “Remember to check both the linters and the tests before creating the Pull Request”
warnings_justification: The set of tools used for examining code quality are listed in contribution-guidelines.md. The project uses eslint is used to look for problems in Javascript. The markdown documentation is scanned with remark and textlint. Docker files are scanned with Hadolint.
warnings_fixed_justification: In general warnings are addressed. In some cases warnings are disabled for specific cases.
warnings_strict_justification: The settings for the warning tools are generally fairly strict.
know_secure_design_justification: The FIWARE Short Time Historic (STH) - Comet development team has developers who know how to design secure software
know_common_errors_justification: The FIWARE Short Time Historic (STH) - Comet development team has developers who know how to design secure software
crypto_published_justification:
This application is a microservice which delegates security to other components such as Keyrock or Keystone. These security components use bcrypt to store salted hashed iterated passwords, and https+standard crypto protocols to communicate with users.

Also, this software use the standard nodeJS libraries (Hapi as a web server and requests as a client) to implement https functionalities.
crypto_call_justification: This software relies on well-known libraries implementing cryptographic.
crypto_floss_justification: The aforementioned libraries use a FLOSS license. https://github.com/hapijs/hapi/blob/master/LICENSE.md https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/LICENSE
crypto_keylength_justification: Cryptographic libraries used by this application and/or the other microservices to which it interacts (Keyrock or Keystone) allow the usage of such minimum key lengths.
crypto_working_justification: The FIWARE Short Time Historic (STH) - Comet doesn’t use any broken cryptographic algorithm.
crypto_pfs_justification: Nothing in the code inhibits or prevents the use of PFS; that is a property of the website's web server.
crypto_random_justification: Cryptographic libraries used by FIWARE Short Time Historic (STH) - Comet and/or the other microservices to which it interacts (Keyrock or Keystone) use randomized mechanisms.
delivery_unsigned_justification: The FIWARE Short Time Historic (STH) - Comet does not cryptographic hashes in any HTTP unsecure endpoint.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: No such vulnerabilities at this time.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: No such vulnerabilities at this time.
static_analysis_justification: The project uses eslint (https://eslint.org/) for this purpose. This analysis tool is used as part of the default test process used in local development, as well as the continuous integration server
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: eslint specifically looks for common vulnerabilities in JavaScript applications.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: This is vacuously true, since we've had no reports of vulnerabilities that apply to a deployed system.
static_analysis_often_justification: All commits to GitHub are run through Github Actions, which performs a number of static analysis checks
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Not applicable, software written using Javascript
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Instead of embedding run-time assertions, there are many external tests with assertions that are checked during automated testing.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: No issues were found by dynamic analysis.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: The FIWARE Short Time Historic (STH) - Comet doesn’t depend on cryptographic algorithms with known vulnerabilities.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Code implements continuous integration based in GitActions. Each time a new pull request is created, the continuous integration system runs the test on it and it is ready to merge only when all tests pass ok. If a problem is found, feedback is provided via GitHub. In addition, several badges on top of the master README.md of the project provide information about the build status in the master branch.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: No valid private credentials appears in public repositories. When some usernames and/or passwords needs to be used, it is never included in repositories and proper mechanism (e.g. Docker secrets) are used at software building and deployment time.
english_justification: All documentation is in English and the project accepts bug reports and comments in English.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
implementation_languages: JavaScript, Python, Gherkin, Shell, API Blueprint, Dockerfile, Makefile

description: Node.js 全栈开发之 Midway.js 2.x 最佳实践
description_good_justification:
在这个项目中，你会看到以下基于 Midway 的实践案例 (上层使用 egg.js )
我们正在做以下工程实践例子，大家你遇到什么问题，或者希望追加什么功能，或者学习内部实现。
可以关注我们的仓库(点赞，分享...三连)在 issue 留言，我们会征集你的意见，带来最干货的案例。
帮你扫清学习障碍，让你用起 Midway 来更加得心应手，提升能效，找回编码的乐趣。

name: DynAdjust
description: DynAdjust is a rigorous, high performance least squares adjustment application. It has been designed to estimate 3D station coordinates and uncertainties for both small and extremely large geodetic networks, and can be used for the adjustment of a large array of Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) and conventional terrestrial survey measurement types. The basic requirement is a C++11 compiler and the installation of dependent packages described in the installation section.
description_good_justification: The https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/blob/master/README.md provides an overview of the software.
interact_justification: The file https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md describes how to obtain, provide feedback and contribute to the software.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
contribution_requirements_justification: The file https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md describes how to contribute.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/raw/master/resources/DynAdjust%20Users%20Guide.pdf
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: GitHub allows for the release of interim versions for review between releases. The version numbering system adopted for DynAdjust releases allows for major, minor and incremental releases.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_tags_justification: Every release is tagged. See https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/tags for a list of tags.
release_notes_justification:
Every release is supplied with release notes using the GitHub.  For example, see the release notes for the last three versions:
- https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/releases/tag/v1.1.0
- https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/releases/tag/v1.0.3
- https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/releases/tag/v1.0.2
release_notes_vulns_justification: This is desirable, although there has not been any need for this yet.
report_tracker_justification: The project uses GitHub's issue tracker at https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/issues
report_process_justification: The project uses GitHub's issue tracker at https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/issues
report_responses_justification: All issues logged at https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/issues have been acknowledged and/or receive a timely response.
enhancement_responses_justification: All issues logged at https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/issues have been acknowledged and/or receive a timely response.
report_archive_justification: GitHub's issue tracker at https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/issues implements a search functionality
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: No vulnerabilities are known to exist.  Vulnerabilities that are discoverd in the future will be reported in https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/blob/master/README.md file and in the release notes https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/releases when identified and resolved.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: The file https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md contains a section on private reports.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No vulnerability reports have been received, nor likely to be received.
build_justification: The software is a C++ project which uses cmake and travis build system (https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/blob/master/.travis.yml).  Testing is implemented via cmake (https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/blob/master/dynadjust/CMakeLists.txt).
build_common_tools_justification: The project can be built with any cmake compliant C++ compiler.
build_floss_tools_justification: The project can be built with any C++ compiler that supports (at least) C++11, including FLOSS versions like the GNU Compiler Collection. No further software is required to build.
test_justification: The project is tested with a unit test suite managed by cmake.  See https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/blob/master/dynadjust/CMakeLists.txt.  The file https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/blob/master/resources/make_dynadjust_gcc.sh provides a way to run tests manually or via continuous integration (CI) script.
test_invocation_justification: The unit tests can be built and executed with a Makefile/CMake target.
test_most_justification: The unit tests cover over 80% of the functions and lines of the project, see https://coveralls.io/github/icsm-au/DynAdjust. The author currently work on improving the branch coverage of the tests.
test_policy_justification: The file https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md instructs contributors how to test their newly added functionality.
tests_are_added_justification: The unit test coverage is checked with every commit and especially reported with every pull request, see https://coveralls.io/github/icsm-au/DynAdjust
tests_documented_added_justification: The file https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md instructs contributors how to test their newly added functionality.
warnings_justification: The test suite is built with extensive compiler warning flags, see https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/blob/master/dynadjust/CMakeLists.txt
warnings_fixed_justification: The main developers have resolved all warnings.  These warnings have been dealt with via several pull requests.
warnings_strict_justification: The project is compiled with all warning flags (-Wall).  See https://github.com/icsm-au/DynAdjust/blob/master/dynadjust/CMakeLists.txt
know_secure_design_justification: Roger Fraser is the primary developer.  Although Roger is aware of such design principles, many of them are not relevant to the project. As and when required, these principles shall be considered for future work.
know_common_errors_justification: The parsing of input files is extremely strict, and relies upon formal parsing schemas with full exception handling.  The test suite covers over 85% of this functionality and as such, no vulnerabilities are known to exist.
delivery_mitm_justification: The project uses GitHub which uses https.
delivery_unsigned_justification: The project uses GitHub which uses https.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: No vulnerabilities are known to exist at this time.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: No vulnerabilities are known to exist at this time.

static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: With every commit and pull request, Codacy (https://app.codacy.com/gh/icsm-au/DynAdjust/dashboard) and Codecov (https://app.codecov.io/gh/icsm-au/DynAdjust) are called to perform static analysis.
static_analysis_often_justification: Coveralls and Codecov are executed on every commit and pull request using .
dynamic_analysis_justification: This will need to be addressed in the future.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: This will need to be addressed in the future.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: The project has not been developed with exception handling throughout. To date, there hasn't been a need for checking the project with assertions, however this will be considered in the future.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: No vulnerabilities have been discovered as yet.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Continuous integration is used for Linux and OS X with Travis (https://travis-ci.org/github/icsm-au/DynAdjust)
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification: All documentation is in English, and the project accepts bug reports and comments in English.

name: gradle
description: Adaptable, fast automation for all
sites_https_justification: Given only https: URLs. We have enabled HSTS and have our domain registered on the HSTS preload list.
description_good_justification:
Write in Java, C++, Python or your language of choice. Package for deployment on any platform. Go monorepo or multi-repo. And rely on Gradle's unparalleled versatility to build it all.
Use Gradle's rich API and mature ecosystem of plugins and integrations to get ambitious about automation. Model, integrate and systematize the delivery of your software from end to end.
Scale out development with elegant, blazing-fast builds. From compile avoidance to advanced caching and beyond, we pursue performance relentlessly so your team can deliver continuously.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/gradle/gradle/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/gradle/gradle/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/userguide.html
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: Source for all include versions are available on GitHub, which uses git.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_semver_justification: The versioning follows something similar to SemVer, however, it's much more simplistic. since 3.0, all of our releases follow the format of `vMAJOR.MINOR.PATCH` with different extensions for intermediate releases (eg. -rc-1, -milestone-1, etc...)
version_tags_justification: Releases are tagged with git and published to GitHub.
release_notes_vulns_justification: Since Gradle 5.6 we have published GitHub security advisories as well as CVE numbers for all vulnerabilities identified. These advisories are linked to in our release notes.
report_responses_justification:
https://github.com/gradle/gradle/blob/master/.github/stale.yml

Gradle leverages the "stale" bot on issues that haven't received any kind of interaction with them for a significant stretch of time.
enhancement_responses_justification:
https://github.com/gradle/gradle/blob/master/.github/stale.yml

Gradle leverages stale to close enhancement requests that haven't received a response for a significant stretch of time
crypto_keylength_justification: The key length requirements and constraints are inherited from the JDK used to execute Gradle. For more information on this topic, see the oracle documentation: https://www.java.com/en/configure_crypto.html
crypto_pfs_justification:
Perfect forward secrecy can be enabled for the JVM by configuring the `jdk.tls.disabledAlgorithms` in `java.security`.

See:
https://security.stackexchange.com/questions/145855/how-to-enforce-perfect-forward-secrecy-using-jvm-properties
crypto_password_storage_justification: Gradle does not store passwords. If passwords are passed into Gradle, they are in memory until the local daemon is killed.
static_analysis_justification: We leverage CodeQL code scanning, but it is not used as a release gate nor is it regularly checked by the Gradle team.
static_analysis_often_justification: CodeQL code scanning is run against every commit against our default branch.
crypto_weaknesses_justification:
Gradle dependency verification can support verifying using SHA 256 signatures.
Recent releases of Gradle support publishing releases to an artifact server with SHA 256 signatures.

Users can explicitly opt-in to using MD5 signatures to verify the integrity of files when using Dependency Verification, but this is not suggested.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
implementation_languages: Groovy, Java, Kotlin, C++, JavaScript, C, XSLT, Scala, Shell, Swift, Objective-C, Objective-C++, GAP, Assembly, Gherkin, Python, Brainfuck, Ruby
dco_justification:
https://github.com/gradle/gradle/blob/master/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md

Gradle leverages DOCO and requires external contributors to sign off on their commits.
sites_password_security_justification: The Gradle Plugin Portal stores passwords using Bcrypt
